comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: The picture has names of the American naval officers written on it. One seems possibly to be Du Pont, Samuel Francis: (1803-1865; Captain, Rear Admiral). See www.wideopenwest.com/~jenkins/ironclads/halloffame.htm A finding aid for his papers is online at www.hagley.org/library/collections/manuscripts/findingaid... in which I find: "There is a significant series of correspondence for the period of the cruise of the Minnesota. Letters received from William B. Reed, American minister to China, document the negotiations that led to the Treaty of Tientsin. Letters from Samuel Wells Williams and Edward W. Syle describe the American missionary movement in China and efforts to eradicate the opium trade." So it seems likely that this picture is from that cruise, which was from 1857 to 1859. Probably taken in China, maybe in Tientsin (aka Tianjin). The treaty was signed in June 1858. Another may be Captain (later Admiral) Franklin Buchanan. See www.history.navy.mil/wars/civilwar.htm

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content:
Great detective work, vintagepix.  The introduction to the finding aid to Du Pont's papers (see link above) says:

"Du Pont returned to Wilmington where he remained until March 22, 1860. When the Japanese sent their first ambassador to the United States, he was asked to serve as an official escort. Together with two fellow officers, Commander Sidney Smith Lee and Lieutenant David Dixon Porter, he accompanied the ambassador's party on a three-month visit to Washington, Baltimore, and Philadelphia. This trip proved to be a major watershed in Japanese-American relations and helped open up Japan to U.S. trade and investment."
